Posts.Content: I think the reason no one has replied to this is that even though I have bone cancer on almost all of my bones, it's pretty much impossible to say what pain is from that & what is normal back ache from doing chores, or from aging, or from arthritis.  Pain is pain & even the doctors can't answer what mine is caused by. So, the best I can say is... good luck!  Toni
Posts.Title: What does bone pain feel like?

Posts.Content: Wow Dave!  Powerful pep-talk!  It made me cry.  I'm sure Lady R will appeciate that and so do I...(even tho' I don't 'know' you)  in fact I'm going to print your letter to remind MYSELF to think the good thoughts.  I'm sure it makes a difference, and I personally, have a lot to be grateful for with my particular 'brand' of Stage IV BC, but any of us can get the blues & your note will be a nice thing to refer to when I'm down.  Thanks for writing it!
Posts.Title: Breast cancer check up

Posts.Content: Hi Kimberly, Get the breast MRI if you have not already done so.  It's an easy test, I had one recently. I have Stage IV lobular breast cancer (no lump) & the 'breast MRI' is one of the few tests that would pick that up.  You just lay face down on a slab that has openings for your breasts to hang thru so as to be isolated from the rest of your body during the scan. Mine was done just to verify my diagnosis which I got in July. Hoping the best for you!
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer infomation

Posts.Content: Hi Becky, I have Stage 4 "bone only" lobular breast cancer which means it is not in my breasts or soft tissues but is in almost all of my bones.  Basically, I feel 'fine', am symptom free, have some bone & joint pain but don't know if that's caused by the cancer or arthritis, or just getting older. I wanted to tell you not to get too excited about her PET scan results because it really is not all that accurate.  Last year I had a nuclear bone scan which indicated that my cancer was worse so I had my first (& only) PET scan 3 weeks after the bone scan & the PET said no visable cancer at all!  When I asked how that was possible they said the PET scan does not show the damage to the bones. So personally I don't know why it's considered a good test.  About 6 yrs ago my husband was given a PET scan due to some chest pain & he was told he had wide spread lung cancer & we thought he'd be dead in about 3 months.  However, when he saw his regular doctor a couple of days later he was told that it showed up so much worse in 2 days that it could not possibly be lung cancer.  It turned out to be pneumonia!  He was treated for that & was just fine.  No cancer then or now.  So I feel that if a PET scan can't even tell the difference between severe lung cancer & pneumonia.... it seems like a worthless & expensive test! I'm sure it must be effective for some patients, but for us, we're 2 for 2 on it being completely wrong! On a better note, tell your sister not to panic because the more she reads these sites, the more people she will hear about who have had bone cancer for many years and live a pretty normal life.  I personally have not changed my lifestyle at all, still do all the same things, work hard, play hard, and I'm good.  I get monthly Zometa, daily Femara pill and just started monthly injection of Faslodex.  Have had no side effects from any of it.  I actually feel quite lucky.  Hope she will be too.... hang in there, may not be as bad as it sounds. Hugs, Toni
Posts.Title: Stage 4 breast/bone cancer

Posts.Content: I have been in a breast cancer clinical trial since last October and my insurance covers it very well. Also, when in a trial the drug company holding the trial is supposed to cover any & all of your out of pocket expenses.  The hospital (doing the trial) didn't tell me that but I heard it from someone & when I asked, they said "yes", they do pay for our hotel bill (we drive 3 1/2 hrs. one way every 3 weeks) & go the day ahead of time so as to be there for an early morning appointment for my chemo.  Otherwise we would be there all day long & have to leave to drive home right at rush hour.  They also cover our meals (on the road & at the hotel) & pay some for mileage. So you may want to ask about your expenses, if any. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Clinical study

Posts.Content: On Feb 26, 2010 2:23 AM chava wrote: Hi , I too have stage IV breast cancer - mets to spine and rib. diag. oct 2007.  Had mri for back pain - could not walk or use legs - found spinal cord compression and bone mets. surgery with rods and pins - no surgery to breast . er+ pr+ Am on arimidex daily and zometa once every two months.  Never had breast surgery - but may soon undecided.  the arimidex has shrunk my breast tumor so much not much breast left. Hang in there -   Hi, my diagnosis is about the same as yours, stage IV lobular breast cancer with mets to back bones, ribs, shoulders, neck, feet & wrist.  But I mostly feel fine!  Very strange!  I'm curious about your back surgery due to compression.... did the surgery fix you up?  Can you walk normally? Move normally? That bone compression on the spinal cord thing is my biggest fear!  Were you told not to lift anything heavy before your bones compressed?  I hope you are doing well after that surgery...  Any info would be appreciated. I have not been able to find many similar cases to my own & still have so many questions... but I'm not in a panic anymore.  Apparently if I have to have a stage IV cancer, this is the one to have.. so I'm thankful.
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: On Feb 23, 2010 11:32 PM jpah123 wrote: Hi, I am awaiting my results form a breast biopsy but was told I probable have stage iv breast cancer that has gone to my bones. I currently have a lower back fravture which brought along other tests to see why this happened. My mamagram came out ok but my CAT scan showed suspicion in my breast along with 6-8 places in my spine, ribs, pelvic, etc. I have been reading a lot I want to start on treatment. I have been suffering with my broken bone in my back for 5 months and feel a lot of pain in the places the CAT scan showed disease. Should I start taking Immunopower, Ultramet, Polymvul or is there soething better. I think the doctors will give me a gloomy outlook but I want to start fighting back right now. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Hi, Have you been given your diagnosis yet?  Your case sounds very similar to mine, depending on what type of cancer you actually have.  You can click on my profile to read about mine, but the bottom line for me is that having Stage IV LOBULAR breast cancer (which was determined by a biopsy to a couple of my vertibrae) is not such a bad thing, so don't panic.  I was diagnosed in July & thought I wouldn't have much time so I gave away a lot of things that I wish I had kept since I really feel just like I did before I knew I had cancer.... some aches & pains, but mostly just fine.  I have no symptoms at all & have been told I can "live for years" with this disease & that seems to be the way Stage IV lobular breast cancer works because I've heard from others who are the same. If your diagnosis is the same, I can go into more detail as far as treatment goes.  I'll be hoping for the best for you.  Write me....... Toni
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: On Feb 27, 2010 7:12 PM denalilin wrote: i also have breast cancer that has gone to my bones. My spine, pelvis, ribs, shoulder & leg. The radiation did help the back pain, reduced some compression on my spinal cord. have to take arimedex for 5 years & will start zometa next month, once a month for at least a year. My diagnosis is not good, however they come out with new treatments every day. So keep the faith. Dont know what the side effects are for zometa yet, the radiation caused nausea & fatigue. I notice a small amount of hair loss, but not significant right now. My son had a glioblastoma brain tumor 3 years ago, the dr. said he had 9 monthe to live, but we never gave up & he is 2 & a half years cancer free. Never let them tell you how long you have. they dont really know. Good luck. I too have stage IV lobular breast cancer which also is in most of my bones.  I've been getting monthly infusions of Zometa since Aug. & have never had any side effects. I'm curious about your back bone compression... that is my biggest fear. How did you know you had it? I guess you did not require surgery for that. (?)  I really have no symptoms other than back ache and pain in the tips of my shoulder bones. I too have mets to my back, ribs, shoulders, neck, feet, and wrist.  But basically, I feel fine. I was diagnosed in July of last year.  When were you diagnosed?    It seems so odd to me that I feel fine and yet have a stage IV cancer! I've had no radiation, chemo or surgery, other than 2 biopsies... not that I'm complaining! I feel very thankful to have this particular type of cancer. I'd appreciate any info you feel like sharing....
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: On Jun 05, 2010 5:00 AM cirlady wrote: My friend was recently told she has ILC.  Going to UM for second opinion on Monday this coming week.  Two weeks ago her nipple looked "normal", today the nipple is looking deformed - her comment.   What's going one from one week to another... I'm concerned.   I have stage IV lobular breast cancer with mets to my bones but it has not ever effected my nipples.  You can tell your friend that ILC is one of the 'better' cancers to have because it's very treatable.  Even tho' I am stage 4, I really have no symptoms other than backache.  I've had no chemo, no radiation & no surgery & just take a daily Femara pill & a monthly infusion of Zometa to strengthen my bones & I've been told by 4 different oncologists in 4 different cities that I can "live for years" with this cancer as long as my meds keep working.  Mostly, I feel fine & have not changed my lifestyle at all.  I feel quite 'lucky' to have this particular cancer. Hope your friend is as lucky..... take care, Toni
Posts.Title: Invasive Lobular Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies, Just wondered how you other stage IV BC patients are doing?  It sounds like there are ast least a few of us who have basically no symptoms.  I, too, feel just like I did before I was told I have cancer.  I have the usual aches & pains, but so does almost everyone else, even those without cancer. My only treatment is a daily Femara pill & a monthly Zometa infusion & I have never had any side effects from either of them until the Zometa infusion last month.  I had LOTS of pain after that one... cried for 2 days, but I've been told that if the 'drip' is set too fast, that causes the bad side effects, so I'm hoping to get it real slow next week & see if that makes the difference.  My kidneys are bad also, apparently from getting too dehydrated a couple of years ago, so now I have to have a bag or 2 of saline before the Zometa so it will flush out of my system faster.  Have to do the same if I have any tests requiring nuclear 'contrast' or iodine.  But I don't mind... as long as it all keeps working! Good luck to all, Toni
Posts.Title: diagnoised with stage iv breast cancer metastasized to bones in spine and pelvic

Posts.Content: I have been taking Femara daily for almost 2 years and I think it's FABULOUS because I am still alive & doing everything I always have done even tho' I have stage IV 'bone only' breast cancer.  I've had no chemo, no radiation, & no surgery. Just my daily Femara and once a month infusion of Zometa along with a monthly shot in my butt of Faslodex. I must take all of it for the rest of my life unless it quits working & I have to switch to another medication.  I am not curable, but I'm "fine"!  I'm VERY happy with Femara!  Hope it's good for your condition as well. Best of Luck, Toni
Posts.Title: Side Effects on Femora

Posts.Content: I certainly have severe pain in my feet but I'm only on Femara and Faslodex & Zometa.  But it seems to me that almost everyone on this site complains about pain in the feet & yet my onc has never heard of that either.  I was dx in July of 09 & have had only these meds i listed.  I just figure it's better than the alternative (of getting worse & dying), so I just keep taking it, which I need to do for the rest of my life.  Hang in there.... Toni
Posts.Title: Aromisin side effects

Posts.Content: I have Stage IV Lobular breast cancer with no symptoms, no surgery, no chemo or radiation. I am on hormone therapy. My CT scan was recently repeated & showed what appeared to be "progressive" metastatic disease even though my CEA numbers have gone from 183 to 12.  My oncologist did not agree it was progressing so I had my first PET scan last week.  That report says "No convincing evidence of metastatic disease in the volume imaged"! also "There is no explanatory artifact or complication such as elevated blood sugar".  What the heck does that mean, and what do I do now??? The cancer could not have disappeared in the 3 weeks in between the 2 tests!?
Posts.Title: CT vs. PET scan?

Posts.Content: I have the same complaints but figure it's worth it because I am still alive!  When I asked the same question here last year someone said to take the Femara at night at bedtime to reduce the side effects & I agree that does make it better.  Yes my legs & feet hurt like crazy but as long as I take my 2 vicodin every 4 hrs, I can do pretty much everything.. chores, work, dance, etc and I see nothing wrong with taking heavy duty pain meds.  They work.  Thank God there are such pills.  One friend said "be careful with those as you could become addicted" but my onc says that's like saying a heart patient is "addicted" to his heart meds.  I'll have to take them for the rest of my life anyway, so who cares.  I wouldn't suggest you skip the Femara as one of my pals did that & her cancer came back worse. Hang in there, Toni
Posts.Title: side effects of Femara

Posts.Content: Like you, I find it hard to trust that it's ok to be just taking a daily pill (mine is Femara) & a monthly injection (mine is Zometa to strengthen my bones) and that's all that is needed to beat my stage IV lobular breast cancer with mets to most of my bones!  However, I recently had my FOURTH "2nd opinion" appt. with a 4th onc in the 4th different big-city-cancer-center (out of state) & they all agree!  I too have had no chemo, no radiation & no surgery other than 2 biopsies, and I too feel just fine!  I have some aches and pains in joints & stuff but I'm happy to be alive to experience that because I sure didn't think I was gonna be!  You would never know I had cancer if I didn't tell you & I look & feel just like I did before!  I persdonally feel VERY grateful that I am not suffering thru' all the same stuff so many people are.... very thankful.  Good luck, Toni
Posts.Title: tomaxofin and nothing else???

Posts.Content: If you are on Taxotere chemotherapy, how many treatments have you had? I just had my 17th treatment which is some kind of record for my Onc . Just wondered if anyone has had more and if so.... How are you doing with side effects, etc.
Posts.Title: Taxotere?

Posts.Content: Like you, I find it hard to trust that it's ok to be just taking a daily pill (mine is Femara) & a monthly injection (mine is Zometa to strengthen my bones) and that's all that is needed to beat my stage IV lobular breast cancer with mets to most of my bones!  However, I recently had my FOURTH "2nd opinion" appt. with a 4th onc in the 4th different big-city-cancer-center (out of state) & they all agree!  I too have had no chemo, no radiation & no surgery other than 2 biopsies, and I too feel just fine!  I have some aches and pains in joints & stuff but I'm happy to be alive to experience that because I sure didn't think I was gonna be!  You would never know I had cancer if I didn't tell you & I look & feel just like I did before!  I persdonally feel VERY grateful that I am not suffering thru' all the same stuff so many people are.... very thankful.  Good luck, Toni
Posts.Title: tomaxofin and nothing else???

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with Stage IV Lobular breast cancer last July.  It was discovered with a CT scan that had been ordered for something else. The cancer is all over my bones, most vertabrae, my hips, pelvis, neck, ribs, shoulders, etc. yet the biopsy of 2 of my vertabrae say it is breast cancer.  I never had any lump... still don't.  I have had no surgery other that a biopsy, no chemo, no radiation, and I have NO SYMPTOMS.  I am being treated with hormone therapy, a daily pill of Femara, a monthly infusion of Zometa to strengthen my bones. Since we live in a small town, I went to 2 other big city cancer centers for their opinions, including City of Hope in L.A. They all say I can "live for years" with this stage 4 cancer, as long as my treatments continue to work.  If and when, this treatment stops working, they say there are several other similar products to try. So far, so good! I too am estrogen positive, but HER2 negative.  My CEA count has gone from 183 in August to 12 as of my last Zometa treatment, so it's working.  All very strange..... What is even more strange is that my CT scan just done in Feb. said that they thought my bone cancer was worse, so then I had a PET scan last Friday, which is supposed to be a better test, and it says "NO EVEIDENCE OF METASTATIC DESEASE"!   No cancer?????? Makes no sense & I still don't have the answer to that one..... Good luck, Toni
Posts.Title: No surgery for advanced breast cancer?????

Posts.Content: Hi Angel, I've been taking Femara daily since last July. I really didn't know it was giving me any side effects at all because I already had arthritis before I was dx with stage IV lobular breast cancer. Since mine is also already in most of my bones, I don't know what causes the aches & pains I feel... arthritis? bone cancer? or the Femara?  Basically I don't complain because apparently the Femara IS working & killing my cancer, so if I have aches and pains.... oh well!..... i'm better than I expected to be at this point!  Hang in there & good luck.  Toni
Posts.Title: Femara users

Posts.Content: I'm hoping to be able to connect with someone else who has Stage 4 Lobular Breast Cancer.  The kind with NO LUMP!  I was diagnosed in July.  Very scary stuff of course, but the good news is that I feel fine.  No symptoms at all!  I am not being given any chemo, radiation or surgery.  No point since it is already in my bones, blood, lymph nodes.  But they tell me I can "live for years" with this.  It doesn't make much sense to me.  I only take a daily Femara pill and once a month infusion of Zometa to make my bones stronger.  I look and feel just like I did before I knew I had cancer.  Is there anyone else out there like me?
Posts.Title: Lobular breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Thank you for responding.  You are the first person I've 'talked' to who has about the same thing. Of course you were only diagnosed a couple of months before me so we are at about the same level, treatment-wise.  I just wish I knew what to expect somewhere down the road.  I recently had a dexascan which is different somehow from a bone scan but shows the bone density.  The results were 'normal', so, thankfully, I guess my bones are healing too, like yours.  It just seems so odd to me that Stage IV is this easy!  Almost makes me glad that I'm not a less advanced stage that would require all the unpleasant treatments and surgeries.
Posts.Title: Lobular breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi, I am so happy to hear that you are doing well 3 years after being diagnosed! Especially if it had spread to your stomach... I thought that would be a very bad thing, but apparently you managed to beat it! Congrats on that!  We live in a small town with no breast cancer support groups so I've been frustrated by having no one to compare notes with.... Can I make you my 'friend' so we can do that? I appreciate the info!  Keep up the good 'work"!  I too have some extra padding around the middle, not sure I can blame it on the meds, may be more likely too much 'comfort food'. I asked my doc if I should still go on a diet, as I had planned, or if it was like on the TV show "Survivor" where the chubby ones last longer, LOL  He said I did not need to go on a diet.  I would like to do some weight training as I used to but not sure that's ok with cancer in my back bones.  I am also having all my original tests repeated now, & so far, so good.  Dexascan on my back was 'normal'  (weird, as you said), CT of my head is 'normal', just had another nuclear bone scan yesterday, no results yet.  Thanks for writing & please keep in touch!  Toni
Posts.Title: Lobular breast cancer?

Posts.Content: On Mar 24, 2010 6:39 PM sgmstage4 wrote: On Feb 12, 2010 2:59 AM deezin wrote: On Jan 28, 2010 5:47 PM Rivergal wrote: Hi, I am so happy to hear that you are doing well 3 years after being diagnosed! Especially if it had spread to your stomach... I thought that would be a very bad thing, but apparently you managed to beat it! Congrats on that!  We live in a small town with no breast cancer support groups so I've been frustrated by having no one to compare notes with.... Can I make you my 'friend' so we can do that? I appreciate the info!  Keep up the good 'work"!  I too have some extra padding around the middle, not sure I can blame it on the meds, may be more likely too much 'comfort food'. I asked my doc if I should still go on a diet, as I had planned, or if it was like on the TV show "Survivor" where the chubby ones last longer, LOL  He said I did not need to go on a diet.  I would like to do some weight training as I used to but not sure that's ok with cancer in my back bones.  I am also having all my original tests repeated now, & so far, so good.  Dexascan on my back was 'normal'  (weird, as you said), CT of my head is 'normal', just had another nuclear bone scan yesterday, no results yet.  Thanks for writing & please keep in touch!  Toni I was diagnosed with Invasive Lobular Breast Cancer stage II in Dec. 09 . My treatment is 6 treatments of chemo which I am starting my 3rd on Monday. Then masectomy then radiation then 5 yrs. on some kind of pill I forgot the name.  My tumor has gotten smaller just after 2 treatments so I know the chemo is working. I am thinking I may not need mastectomy if it is smaller maybe I will need a lumpectomy It's all so confusing. How come you aren't getting chemo with stage 4? My prayers are with you all Diane Hi Toni!  Where do you live!!??   I just had all of my tests repeated, including the stomach scope, and all clear.......weird!!!  As usual.  I have weight gain, which I HATE, and extreme fatigue, joint pain.  Wish I had a solution for that, but I am alive three years later!  I am trying to figure out ways to battle the side effects.....not much luck so far!  How are you doing?  what about side effects???   shirley in Ga. Hi Shirley, It looks like I never replied to this note... if so, I'm sorry.  I didn't know I had a message. I don't remember getting any notice of it.... anyway, we live in southern Oregon.  I get my treatment of Zometa at the new (small) cancer center here but I verified that it was the right thing ay both a large teaching medical center in Portland & at City of Hope in LA. Now I'm confused though because in doing the 6 mo repeat of all my scans, the CT radiologist referred to my bone cancer as 'progressive', even though my CEA count has come down to 12, from a high of 183. So then my onc ordered my first PET scan, which was last week.  The resuls of that say "No convincing evidence of metastatic disease in the volume imaged"!  What the heck does that mean?  I'm pleased that the PET scan didn't indicate that the cancer is worse, but it couldn't have just disappeared in 3-4 WEEKS! Not sure where to go from here.... my onc is supposed to talk with the radiologists who read the 2 scans & see what THEY think. As for side effects.... I didn't know I had any, LOL because I've been blaiming all my aches & pains on aging, arthritis, cold & damp weather, etc. but maybe some of my pain is from SE's.  I have thinning hair, joint pain, really sore tops of my feet sometimes & I've noticed others have mentioned their feet hurting.  I wear an over-the-counter Wal Mart back brace most of the time because it really does help my back pain.  I take 2 vicoden when I remember to do that but I'm terrible with pills, even tho' I take about 16 per day.  I take so many suppliments, etc. that more pills, even to releive pain, just does not appeal to me.  I get tired too, but I work hard all the time... just a high maintenence house & yard.... and I feel like anyone would be tired with my burn-the-candle-at-both-ends lifestyle.  I need to make time for some actual cardio excercize, but can't seem to get there. I'm glad to hear you are doing so well, YAY!  Strange as it is, I'll take it... if I have to have a stage IV cancer, I guess this is the one to have!  Take care, Toni
Posts.Title: Lobular breast cancer?
